facts.text: Petition No. 98 of 1956 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 98 of 1956. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta and, according to him, he enjoys credit and reputation in the market as a well-known and respectable broker of such goods.

facts.text: On May 4, 1955, Rummaging Inspector Intelligence, Customs House, Calcutta (Respondent No. 3) searched petitioner's residential room at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta with search warrant from Chief Presidency Magistrate (Respondent No. 4).

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1955, the Rummaging Inspector  Intelligence , Customs House, Calcutta, Respondent No. 3, armed with a search warrant from the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, Respondent No. 4, searched the residential room of the petitioner, situated at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta,

facts.text: Search of steel almirah found no diamonds; petitioner denied having any diamonds.

anchor.surface_text: and after a minute search of the steel almirah in which according to the statement of the petitioner, he used to keep his stock in trade and finding numbere there questioned him as to where he had secreted the diamonds to which the 1112 reply given by him was in the negative.

facts.text: 475 pieces of diamonds and one piece of synthetic stone discovered in old jacket in wall almirah.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a wall almirah, wherein washed clothes, and other articles were stored, was searched and therein in an old jacket 475 pieces of diamonds were discovered along with one piece of synthetic stone.

facts.text: Petitioner's statement: Rs. 10,000 worth diamonds from M/s. Ratilal Amritlal, Bombay; rest purchased locally without records.

anchor.surface_text: A statement signed by him was taken from which we find that his explanation for the possession was that Rs. 10,000/- worth of diamonds were received by him from M s. Ratilal Amritlal, of 89 Zaveri Bazar, Bombay, and the rest were purchased locally in Calcutta.

facts.text: Assistant Collector permitted petitioner time till May 7, 1955 to produce evidence of legal import.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector then permitted the petitioner to go and gave him time till May 7, 1955, to produce evidence showing that the goods were imported on payment of customs duty and under a valid import licence.

facts.text: Notice served on May 4, 1955 requiring documents by May 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, i.e., May 4, 1955, a numberice was served on the petitioner by the Customs authorities stating that there were reasonable grounds to believe that the goods seized by the Rummaging Inspector had been illegally imported into India

facts.text: Petitioner's advocates wrote to Assistant Collector on May 7, 1955 requesting reasons and time.

anchor.surface_text: In answer to this, on behalf of the petitioner Messrs. S. K. Sawday and Company, a firm of Advocates, Calcutta, wrote to the Assistant Collector, Customs, on May 7, 1955, reciting the circumstances under which the petitioner came to 1113 be in possession of the seized articles

facts.text: Further correspondence: letters on May 9, May 16, May 23 (reply), June 20, June 25, July 1, July 4, July 20.

anchor.surface_text: Another letter was written by the same firm of Advocates on May 9, 1955, the details of which it is unnecessary to refer. On May 16, 1955, a further letter was written enclosing two certificates and companytaining further particulars.
A personal hearing was granted on July 21, 1955, followed by a letter from the Advocates 1114 dated July 22, 1955.

facts.text: Collector of Customs passed order on September 12, 1955, dispatched November 5, 1955, confiscating diamonds under ss. 167(8) and 167(39).

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Customs thereupon, after companysidering the entire matter placed before him, passed an order dated September 12, 1955, which was dispatched on November 5, 1955, companytaining an elaborate discussion of the various facts and circumstances

facts.text: Petitioner failed to discharge onus under s. 178-A; presumption not rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: finally companycluding that since the petitioner had failed to discharge the onus under s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act in respect of the diamonds seized on May 4, 1955, orders had been passed companyfiscating the same

facts.text: Petitioner did not appeal to Central Board of Revenue, directly approached Supreme Court under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: Without availing himself of that remedy the petitioner has companye up to this Court by way of an application for a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 8, 1957 by GOVINDA MENON, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. May 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GOVINDA MENON, J.-This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the companystitutionality of s. 178-A,

facts.text: Section 178-A inserted by s. 14 of Amending Act XXI of 1955 in Sea Customs Act, 1878.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the companystitutionality of s. 178-A, inserted in the Sea Customs Act,  VIII of 1878 , by s. 14 of the Amending Act XXI of 1955,

anchor.surface_text: It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. issues.text: Whether Section 178-A of the Sea Customs Act, inserted by Section 14 of Amending Act XXI of 1955, is constitutional, particularly whether it offends Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the constitutionality of s. 178-A, inserted in the Sea Customs Act, VIII of 1878, by s. 14 of the Amending Act XXI of 1955, and the chief ground on which it is sought to be struck down is that it offends Art. 14 of the Constitution. From the affidavits of both

issues.text: Whether Section 178-A violates Articles 19(1)(f), 19(1)(g) and 31 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Though Mr. Chatterjee faintly argued that the provisions of Art. 19(1)(f) and (g) and Art. 31 of the Constitution had been violated, he did not seriously press those contentions. The main point of the attack was centered on the contention that s. 178-A was violative of the principles of equal protection of the laws guaranteed under Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the reverse burden of proof under Section 178-A is opposed to principles of natural justice and results in arbitrary power, violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: the burden of proof enunciated therein is opposed to fundamental principles of natural justice, as it gives an unrestricted arbitrary and naked power to the customs authorities without laying down any standard or norm to be followed for exercising powers under the section.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test

arguments.claim: s.178-A based on well-defined classification of easily smuggled goods seized on reasonable belief

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 178-A will at once disclose the well defined classification of goods based on an intelligible differentia. It applies only to certain goods described in sub-s.

arguments.claim: Classification and presumption in s.178-A have rational nexus to object of preventing smuggling

anchor.surface_text: The differentia on the basis of which the goods have been classified and the presumption raised by the section obviously have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved

arguments.claim: s.178-A enacted to implement Taxation Enquiry Commission recommendation to shift onus and minimize smuggling

anchor.surface_text: The genesis of s. 178-A may not be considered. The Central Government had appointed a commission known as the Taxation Enquiry Commission which by its report recommended the adoption

arguments.claim: Sea Customs Act is complete code with successive remedies including adjudication, appeal, revision

anchor.surface_text: The outline of the various provisions above made shows that successive remedies are provided to an aggrieved person from whom articles have been seized and confiscated and the Act

holdings.text: s. 178-A does not offend Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: there can be nodoubt whatever that s. 178-A does number offend Art. 14. The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section satisfies Art.14 reasonable classification test: intelligible differentia (specified easily smuggled goods seized on reasonable belief) and rational nexus to preventing smuggling, following Budhan Chaudhury precedent.

holdings.text: Classification under s. 178-A founded on intelligible differentia distinguishing easily smuggled goods

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 178-A will at once disclose the well defined classification of goods based on an intelligible differentia. It applies only to certain goods described in sub-s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis shows section applies only to gold, diamonds etc., seized under Act in reasonable belief of smuggling.

holdings.text: Presumption under s. 178-A has rational relation to object of preventing smuggling

anchor.surface_text: The differentia on the basis of which the goods have been classified and the presumption raised by the section obviously have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption attaches only to specified goods, furthers legislative aim of anti-smuggling by easing proof in clandestine cases.

holdings.text: Provisions of s. 178-A do not violate Art. 19(1)(f), (g) or Art. 31

anchor.surface_text: Though Mr. Chatterjee faintly argued that the provisions of Art. 19(1)(f) and (g) and Art. 31 of the Constitution had been violated, he did number seriously press those contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arguments faintly made and not seriously pressed by petitioner; main challenge under Art.14 rejected.

holdings.text: Reverse burden under s. 178-A not opposed to natural justice or arbitrary under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: Confining as it does to certain classes of goods seized by the customs authorities on the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, there is only a presumption which can be rebutted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption rebuttable, applies narrowly with procedural safeguards; satisfies equal protection via classification test.

holdings.text: Sea Customs Act is a complete code providing successive remedies for aggrieved persons

anchor.surface_text: The outline of the various provisions above made shows that successive remedies are provided to an aggrieved person from whom articles have been seized and confiscated and the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed provisions for adjudication, appeal, revision afford redress against unjustified seizures.
